title: What are some good ways to write a good narrative hook? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some of it will depend on genre, but some aspects of writing the first few sentences of a story (whatever the length of story) will hold. You need tension and story questions, even if you’re only establishing a setting. For example: No amount of sunscreen and shade could soften the hot, Arizona day. There’s an implied person or people in that sentence, which adds interest, and the time setting has to be fairly modern, or at least since the advent of sunscreen. There’s some tension there, because heat is uncomfortable. You can do better. How about piquing some interest by twisting expectations? Melissa decided that if there was such a thing as a hot hell, this would be it. We expect hell to be hot, so the specificity of hot hell, not just ‘if there was such a thing as hell’ is interesting. The character is simply deciding something, though, and that’s static. Melissa decided that if there was such a thing as a hot hell, this would be it, as she took aim with her Barrett MRAD. Now we’ve got story questions in addition to the somewhat quirky phrasing. What is she aiming at? As you progress from the first sentence, ideally you want to answer some questions, especially the ones that readers expect to be answered right away. You don’t want to hold back too much, because the reader will get upset with you. Normal beginner ‘cheats’ that come off as cheap gimmicks include never naming the primary or point of view character, even when their name would naturally come up, being evasive about the pov character’s identity in other ways so that their role is so ambiguous you start to wonder if they’re simply an AI robot, being evasive about the setting, and so on. But you don’t have to give it all away, either. You can plan your reveals. As long as you keep the narrative lively, and keep the information flowing, you can arrange that information just about any way you like. As you progress into the rest of the paragraph and beyond, you’ll want to continue to add story questions. Usually those story questions get bigger, but less frequent, with an underlying ‘what’s going to happen next?’ holding it all together. There are some really good books on how to begin stories. You should try some of them. I usually point people to Writing Active Hooks Book 1: Action, Emotion, Surprise and More - Kindle edition by Mary Buckham. Reference Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com. as a good starting point. I’ve learned some great stuff from Mary Buckham’s other books as well. I hope this helps!

A text driven by narrative would benefit first from thoroughly establishing the ‘credentials’ of the narrator (storyteller) as authentic. So the “hook” I am suggesting is simply that authenticity. With the narrator settled as a plausibly-accurate relator (one who relates, not a realtor), your book will by virtue of that have a tone substantially informed by the narrator as a reliable source. Many readers seek the “voice” of the narrator as presumably God-given. It's a rather old reference, but there was a minor public figure named Euell Gibbons who often appeared in U.S. TV commercials (for Post® Grape Nuts breakfast cereal) and became famous for saying things like: Ever eat a pine tree? Many parts are edible.I think it bears mentioning that this “public figure” instantly evaporated from TV-space upon his death at age 64. Prior to that he was presumably regarded as a wise elder! TV ad “marketing” is/was surely a fickle undertaking. A narrator is only as good as his or her PR (public relations—meaning perceived status in society). The beloved actress-cum-talk-show-host Oprah Winfrey is just the sort of believable narrator I would strive to emulate. She practices her elocution like any skilled actor, and “speaks from the heart.” Another believable voice often pressed into narrating some corporate or charity organization’s message is the redoubtable senior and Oscar®-winning actor Morgan Freeman, also known as “the voice of God.” My final suggestion is to read The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Mark Twain’s classic of the genre, noting how plain-spoken yet compelling the captured-African Huck is when telling his own life story. That book is a real “page-turner.” I didn't set out to present African Americans as the only believable narrators. The legendary poet-activist and performer John Trudell’s voice was/is another great one telling stories. Trudell passed away at age 69 in 2015. His poetry and recordings will long outlive him. Your narrator need not be a senior citizen! There's another possible hook: a child’s innocence informs your otherwise-flawed [childlike-language] text (warning: I'm fairly sure it's already been done).
